TEXT.English: [TAB]A triumphal arch is a structure in the shape of a monumental archway, usually built to celebrate a victory in war. The arch is invariably a free-standing structure, quite separate from city gates or walls. In its simplest form a triumphal arch consists of two pillars connected by an arch, crowned with a superstructure or attic on which a statue or commemorative inscriptions might be mounted. More elaborate triumphal arches have flanking subsidiary archways, typically a pair. Famous arches include the Arch of Titus in Rome and the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un arc de triomphe est un ouvrage en forme d'arche monumentale, généralement construit pour célébrer une victoire à la guerre. L'arc est toujours une structure indépendante, à l'écart des portes et des remparts de la ville. Dans sa forme la plus simple, l'arc de triomphe se compose de deux piliers reliés par un arc et surmontés d'un entablement ou d'un attique sur lequel peuvent être ajoutées une statue ou des inscriptions commémoratives. Les arcs de triomphe plus élaborés comportent des arches secondaires - généralement au nombre de deux - sur les côtés. Parmi les arcs de triomphes les plus célèbres, on trouve l'Arc de Titus à Rome et l'Arc de triomphe de l'Etoile à Paris.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Triumphbogen ist ein frei stehendes Bauwerk in Form eines monumentalen Tors oder Bogengangs, das üblicherweise zur Würdigung eines bedeutenden militärischen Sieges abseits von Stadttoren oder -mauern errichtet wird. In seiner einfachsten Form besteht ein Triumphbogen aus zwei Säulen, die durch einen Bogen verbunden und mit einer Attika versehen sind, auf der eine Statue thront oder eine Inschrift angebracht ist. Aufwändiger gearbeitete Triumphbögen haben zusätzlich noch angrenzende Seitenbogengänge, die meist paarweise angeordnet sind. Berühmte Triumphbögen sind beispielsweise der Titusbogen in Rom und der Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un arco di trionfo è una struttura con la forma di una monumentale arcata, spesso costruita per celebrare la vittoria in una guerra. L'arco è invariabilmente una struttura a sé stante, separata dalle mura o dalle porte di una città. Nella sua forma più semplice un arco di trionfo consiste di due colonne unite da un arco, sovrastato da una struttura o un attico su cui si possono trovare statue o iscrizioni. Gli archi di trionfo più elaborati possono avere arcate sussidiarie laterali, di solito una coppia. Tra i più famosi sono l'Arco di Tito a Roma e l'Arco di Trionfo a Parigi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un Arco de Triunfo es una enorme arcada monumental que se suele construir para celebrar una victoria en la guerra. El arco siempre es una estructura solitaria, separada de las puertas o muros de la ciudad. En su forma más sencilla consiste en dos pilares conectados por un arco que a su vez está coronado por una estructura superior en la cual se suele colocar una estatua o una inscripción conmemorativa. Los Arcos de Triunfo más elaborados pueden tener un par de arcos secundarios en los laterales. Los más famosos son el Arco de Tito en Roma y el Arco del Triunfo de Paris.

[TAB]The Leaning Tower of Pisa, or simply The Tower of Pisa (Italian: La Torre di Pisa) is the campanile, or freestanding bell tower, of the cathedral of the Italian city of Pisa. It is situated behind the Cathedral and it is the third structure in Pisa's Campo dei Miracoli (field of Miracles). The tower is the most famous leaning building in the world. While intended to stand vertically, it began leaning to the southeast soon after the onset of construction in 1173 due to a poorly laid foundation and loose substrate that has allowed the foundation to shift.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La tour de Pise, que les Italiens appellent "torre di Pisa", est le campanile (clocher isolé) de la cathédrale de Pise, en Italie. Située derrière la cathédrale, elle est le troisième bâtiment sur la place des miracles de la ville. La tour est le plus célèbre des bâtiments penchés au monde. Verticale à l'origine, elle commença à s'incliner vers le sud-est peu après le début de sa construction en 1173, ses fondations glissant sur le sous-sol trop meuble.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der schiefe Turm von Pisa (Italienisch: La Torre di Pisa) ist ein "Campanile", ein frei stehender Glockenturm des Doms von Pisa. Er befindet sich auf der Rückseite des Doms und ist als drittes Bauwerk auf Pisas "Piazza dei Miracoli" (Platz der Wunder) das wohl bekannteste schiefe Gebäude der Welt. Das Gebäude sollte gemäß der Bauplaner normal gerade stehen, doch kurz nach Baubeginn im Jahr 1173 bekam es wegen eines Grundbruches, dem Nachgeben des Fundamentes, eine Schräglage Richtung Südosten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La torre pendente di Pisa, o semplicemente la torre di Pisa è il campanile della cattedrale di Pisa. Si trova dietro la cattedrale ed è la terza struttura nel Campo dei Miracoli. La torre è il più famoso edificio pendente al mondo. Pur essendo stata progettata per rimanere verticale, cominciò a pendere poco dopo l'inizio dei lavori di costruzione nel 1173, a causa di fondamenta mal realizzate e di un sottostrato friabile che ha permesso alle fondamenta di spostarsi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Torre Inclinada de Pisa, o simplemente la Torre de Pisa, es una torre campanario individual de la catedral de la ciudad italiana de Pisa. Está situada detrás de la catedral y es la tercera estructura del "Campo dei Miracoli" de Pisa ("Campo de los Milagros"). La torre es el edificio inclinado más famoso del mundo. Aunque se pretendía que fuera totalmente vertical, comenzó a inclinarse hacia el sudeste poco después de su construcción, en 1173, debido a unos cimientos defectuosos y la tierra reblandecida sobre la que reposa.

TEXT.English: National Gallery

[TAB]A national gallery is a country's major public art gallery. With different names, they are widespread in almost every nation capital. They are a space for the exhibition of art, usually visual art, and usually primarily paintings, illustrations, and sculpture. The art museum is considered a fairly modern invention, the first being the Louvre in Paris, which was established in 1793, soon after the French Revolution when the royal treasures were declared for the people.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une galerie nationale est la principale galerie d'art ouverte au public dans un pays. Bien que les appellations changent suivant les pays, on en trouve une dans presque chaque capitale du monde. Ces bâtiments servent à exposer les arts _ généralement visuels _ et notamment les peintures, les illustrations et les sculptures. On considère que le musée d'art est une invention assez moderne ; le plus ancien est le Louvre, qui ouvrit en 1793, peu après la Révolution française, lorsque les trésors royaux ont été déclarés propriété du peuple.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Nationalgalerie ist die größte öffentlich zugängliche Kunstgalerie eines Landes. Diese Galerien sind unter verschiedenen Bezeichnungen in fast allen Hauptstädten weit verbreitet und dienen als Ausstellungsorte für Kunst, meist bildende Kunst, und zwar in erster Linie für Gemälde, Illustrationen und Skulpturen. Das Kunstmuseum als solches ist eine relativ moderne Einrichtung: Die erste Institution dieser Art war der Pariser Louvre, der erst 1793 - kurz nach der französischen Revolution - gebaut wurde, nachdem die königlichen Schätze per Dekret dem Volk zugänglich gemacht worden waren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una galleria nazionale è la principale galleria d'arte pubblica di una nazione. Con diversi nomi se ne trovano in quasi ogni capitale. Sono uno spazio per l'esibizione dell'arte, solitamente visiva, e principalmente dipinti, illustrazioni e sculture. Il museo d'arte è considerato un'invenzione abbastanza moderna: il primo è quello del Louvre a Parigi fondato nel 1793, poco dopo la rivoluzione francese, quando i tesori reali vennero dichiarati di proprietà del popolo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una galería nacional es un gran museo de arte público de un país. Recibe diferentes nombres, pero casi todas las capitales del mundo cuentan con una de ellas. Hay un espacio para la exhibición de elementos artísticos, normalmente artes visuales, fundamentalmente pintura, ilustración y escultura. El museo de arte se considera una invención relativamente moderna. El primero de ellos fue el Louvre en París, fundado en 1793, al poco de finalizar la Revolución Francesa y tras declarar públicos los bienes de la realeza.

TEXT.English: Opera House

[TAB]An opera house is a building where operas are performed. The venues are usually constructed specifically with opera in mind, although other performing arts may be performed there. Notable opera houses include London's Globe Theater, where most of the plays of William Shakespeare were first performed on the stage, the Sydney Opera House, one of the most distinctive and famous 20th century buildings and La Scala in Milan.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un opéra est un bâtiment où sont représentés les opéras. Les lieux sont généralement pensés pour l'opéra, mais peuvent servir pour d'autres représentations artistiques. Parmi les opéras les plus célèbres, on trouve le théâtre du Globe de Londres, où eut lieu la première représentation de la plupart des oeuvres de William Shakespeare, l'opéra de Sydney, l'un des bâtiments les plus marquants et les plus célèbres du XXe siècle, et la Scala de Milan.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Opernhaus ist ein Gebäude, in dem Opern aufgeführt werden. Es ist baulich normalerweise speziell für derartige Aufführungen konzipiert, es können aber auch andere darstellende Künste dargeboten werden. Berühmte Opernhäuser sind zum Beispiel das Globe Theatre in London, in dem die meisten Stücke von William Shakespeare uraufgeführt wurden, das Sydney Opera House, eins der markantesten und berühmtesten Bauwerke des 20. Jahrhunderts, sowie das Teatro alla Scala in Mailand.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un teatro dell'opera è un teatro in cui vengono rappresentate le opere. Solitamente sono costruiti in maniera specifica con in mente l'opera, anche se vi si possono tenere anche altri spettacoli. Fra i teatri dell'opera più conosciuti si annovera anche il Globe Theatre di Londra, in cui vennero rappresentati per la prima volta quasi tutti i lavori di Shakespeare, e il teatro dell'opera di Sydney, uno dei più particolari e famosi edifici del 20° secolo, oltre alla Scala di Milano.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un Teatro de la Ópera es un edificio en el que se interpretan óperas. Las instalaciones se suelen construir específicamente para la representación de óperas, aunque también pueden albergar otro tipo de actuaciones. Algunos de los teatros de ópera más famosos son el Globe Theatre de Londres, donde se presentaron la mayoría de las obras de William Shakespeare por primera vez, la Opera House de Sydney, uno de los edificios más famosos del siglo XX y La Scala de Milán.
TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Oïåðà (èòàë. opera «äåëî, òðóä, ðàáîòà; îïåðà», èç ëàò. opera «òðóä, èçäåëèå, ïðîèçâåäåíèå») - æàíð òåàòðàëüíûõ ïðåäñòàâëåíèé, â êîòîðîì ðå÷ü, ñîåäèíåííàÿ ñ ìóçûêîé (ïåíèå è àêêîìïàíåìåíò, è ñöåíè÷åñêîå äåéñòâèå èìåþò ïðåîáëàäàþùåå çíà÷åíèå.Êðóïíîå ìóçûêàëüíîå ïðîèçâåäåíèå, â êîòîðîì îáúåäèíåíû ðàçëè÷íûå âèäû èñêóññòâà.

TEXT.English: The Tower of London

[TAB]Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress, more commonly known as the Tower of London (and historically as The Tower), is a historic fortress and scheduled monument in central London, England, on the north bank of the River Thames. It is located within the London Borough of Tower Hamlets and is separated from the eastern edge of the City of London by the open space known as Tower Hill. It is the oldest building used by the British government.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Tower of London is often identified with the White Tower, the original stark square fortress built by William the Conqueror in 1078. However, the tower as a whole is a complex of several buildings set within two concentric rings of defensive walls and a moat.[PARAGRAPH:1]The tower's primary function was a fortress, a royal palace, and a prison (particularly for high status and royal prisoners, such as the Princes in the Tower and the future Queen Elizabeth I). This last use has led to the phrase "sent to the Tower" (meaning "imprisoned"). It has also served as a place of execution and torture, an armoury, a treasury, a zoo, the Royal Mint, a public records office, an observatory, and since 1303, the home of the Crown Jewels of the United Kingdom.
Versailles

[TAB]A palace is the home of a head of state or other high-ranking public figure. Many palaces are now put to other uses such as parliaments or museums. Heads of State, especially monarchs, usually spend some weeks each year in other palaces that are not their primary residence. Such palaces are often called Winter Palaces or Summer Palaces, depending on the season they are used. A few examples are the Russian Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, the Chinese Summer Palace in Beijing, and the Kucuksu Summer Palace in Istanbul.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un palais est un lieu où réside un chef d'Etat ou un personnage public important. Beaucoup de palais ont aujourd'hui été reconvertis en parlements ou en musées. Les chefs d'Etat, et principalement les monarques, passent généralement quelques semaines par an dans des palais secondaires. Ces palais sont souvent appelés palais d'hiver ou palais d'été, suivant la saison à laquelle ils sont occupés. On peut citer, par exemple, le palais d'hiver de Saint-Pétersbourg en Russie, le palais d'été de Beijing en Chine, et le palais d'été de Küçüksu à Istanbul.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Residenz ist der Wohnsitz eines Staatsoberhaupts oder einer anderen hochrangigen Person des öffentlichen Lebens. Viele Residenzen dienen heute als Parlamentssitze oder Museen. Staatsoberhäupter, insbesondere Monarchen, leben in der Regel einige Wochen im Jahr nicht in ihrem Hauptwohnsitz, sondern (je nach Jahreszeit) in ihren so genannten Winter- oder Sommerresidenzen. Beispiele hierfür sind der russische Winterpalast in St. Petersburg, der chinesische Sommerpalast in Peking und der Kücüksu-Sommerpalast in Istanbul.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un palazzo è la casa di un capo di stato o di un'altra importante figura pubblica. Molti palazzi ora sono adibiti a usi diversi, come parlamenti o musei. I capi di stato, specialmente i monarchi, passano qualche settimana ogni anno in palazzi che non sono la loro residenza primaria. Solitamente sono chiamati palazzo d'inverno o d'estate, a seconda della stagione in cui vengono usati. Un esempio sono il Palazzo d'Inverno a San Pietroburgo, il Palazzo d'Estate a Pechino e il Palazzo d'Estate Kucuksu a Istanbul.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un palacio es el hogar del jefe de estado o de otro personaje público de alto rango. Hoy en día, muchos palacios se usan para cosas diferentes, por ejemplo, como sedes del Parlamento o museos. Los cabezas de estado, especialmente los monarcas, solían pasar algunas semanas del año fuera de su residencia habitual, en otros palacios. Dichos edificios solían recibir el nombre de palacios de invierno o de verano, en función de la estación en la que fueran utilizados. Algunos ejemplos son el Palacio de Invierno ruso de San Petersburgo, el Palacio de Verano chino de Pekín, y el Palacio de Kucuksu, de verano, en Estambul.

TEXT.English: Trading Company

[TAB]A trading company is an association formed by investors or shareholders for the purpose of trade, exploration and colonisation. Typically, these companies were formed from the sixteenth century onwards by groups of European investors to underwrite and profit from the exploration of Africa, India, the Caribbean and North America, usually under the patronage of one state, which issued the company's charter. Notable companies include British East India Company and Dutch Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une compagnie marchande est une association formée par des investisseurs ou des actionnaires s'intéressant au commerce, à l'exploration et à la colonisation. Ces compagnies furent créées à partir du XVIe siècle, généralement par des investisseurs européens, pour financer l'exploration de l'Afrique, de l'Inde, des Caraïbes et de l'Amérique du Nord, et bien sûr en tirer profit. Elles étaient généralement sous le patronage d'un Etat, qui leur accordait une charte. Parmi les compagnies les plus connues, on peut citer la British East India Company (Compagnie anglaise des Indes orientales) et la Dutch Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie (Compagnie hollandaise des Indes orientales).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Handelsgesellschaft ist eine von Investoren oder Aktionären gebildete Interessengemeinschaft zum Zwecke des Handels, der Ausbeutung und der Kolonialisierung. Derartige Gesellschaften wurden seit dem 16. Jahrhundert von europäischen Investoren gebildet, um sich den Anspruch auf die privilegierte Ausbeutung Afrikas, Indiens, Nordamerikas und des karibischen Raumes sowie die damit verbundenen Profite zu sichern, üblicherweise unter der Führung eines Staates, der den Freibrief für die Gesellschaft ausstellte. Bedeutende Gesellschaften dieser Art waren die Britische Ostindien-Kompanie und die Niederländische Ostindien-Kompanie.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una compagnia commerciale è un'associazione formata da investitori o azionisti con lo scopo di commerciare, esplorare e colonizzare. Queste compagnie nacquero a partire dal sedicesimo secolo per volontà di investitori europei, che desideravano finanziare e approfittare dell'esplorazione di Africa, India, Caraibi e Nord America, solitamente con l'appoggio di uno stato, che emetteva l'atto costitutivo della società. Tra le più famose ci sono la Compagnia delle Indie Orientali Britannica e la Compagnia Olandese delle Indie Orientali.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una compañía de las Indias es una asociación de inversores o accionistas cuyos fines son promocionar el comercio, la exploración y la colonización. Estas compañías se formaron a partir del siglo XVI por grupos de inversores europeos que querían financiar la exploración de África, la India, el Caribe y el norte de América, normalmente bajo la tutela de un estado, que emitía la carta real o los estatutos de la compañía. Algunas de las más notables fueron la británica Compañía de las Indias Orientales y la Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie holandesa.

[TAB]The Alhambra is a palace and fortress complex of the Moorish monarchs of Granada, in southern Spain (known as Al-Andalus when the fortress was constructed), occupying a hilly terrace on the south-eastern border of the city of Granada. It was the residence of the Muslim kings of Granada and their court, but is currently a museum exhibiting exquisite Islamic architecture. A Renaissance palace was also inserted by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.[PARAGRAPH:1]The name Alhambra, signifying in Arabic the red, derives from the colour of the red clay of the surroundings of which the fort is made. The buildings of the Alhambra were originally whitewashed; however, the buildings now seen today are reddish. The first reference to the Qal'at al Hamra was during the battles between the Arabs and the Muladies during the rule of the Abdallah (who reigned from 888-912). In one particularly fierce and bloody skirmish, the Muladies soundly defeated the Arabs who were then forced to take shelter in a primitive red castle located in the province of Elvira, nowadays located in Granada. According to surviving documents from the era, the red castle was quite small and its walls were not capable of deterring army intent on conquering. The castle was then largely ignored until the eleventh century when its ruins were renovated and rebuilt by Samuel ibn Naghralla, vizier to the King Badis of the Zirid Dynasty, in an attempt to preserve the small Jewish settlement also located on the Sabikah hill. However, evidence from Arab texts indicates that the fortress was easily penetrated and that the actual Alhambra that survives today was built during the Nasrid Dynasty. -Wikipedia

TEXT.English: The Alhambra
Theodosian Walls

[TAB]The original walls of Constantinople were built in the 8th century BC when Byzantium was founded by Greek colonists from Megara. At the time the city consisted of an acropolis and little more. The colony was relatively unimportant by the Roman period, but Septimius Severus built a new set of walls during his reign, bringing more land into the city. When Constantine moved the capital of the empire to Byzantium, which he renamed Constantinople, he greatly expanded the walls of the city, incorporating even more territory.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 412 the Roman emperor Theodosius II surrounded Constantinople with a wall that stretched 6.5 kilometers between the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn. Although named after Theodosius, they were actually constructed under the direction of Anthemius, Praetorian prefect of the Eastern Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The walls were built of stone and brick in two lines of defense which adjoined a ditch 20 meters wide and 10 meters deep. The inner wall had was 5 meters thick and 12 meters high. It was strengthened with 96 unapproachable towers 18-20 meters tall. The thickness of the external wall was 2 meters, and its height was 8.5 meters. The wall contained the Belgrad, Silivrikapi, Mevlevihane, Topkapi, Edirnekapi, Egrikapi and Yedikule gates. Yedikule Gate was also known as the "Porta Aurea" or "Golden Gate", and was the most magnificent, consisting of three archways. As the state entrance into the capital, the Golden Gate was architecturally splendid, and was built of large square blocks of polished marble fitted together without cement, and flanked by two great towers of the same material. Upon the gates were placed sculpted elephants.[PARAGRAPH:2]The inner walls had massive square or hexagonal towers. The southern end of the walls, at the Sea of Marmara, was the location of the Marble Tower. There were ten gates, the four major ones being the Golden Gate at the southern end, the Selymbria Gate leading to the Forum of Constantine and Hagia Sophia, the Adrianople Gate connecting Constantinople's Mese (the main street) with the city of Adrianople and the Via Egnatia, and the Blachernae Gate in the north.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 439 the first sea walls were built. In 447 the wall was damaged by an earthquake, but was quickly restored in time to stop Attila's army. In the northwestern corner of the city, in the suburb of Blachernae, the Theodosian walls were relatively weaker, but were expanded by Leo I. The northern coast of the city, along the Golden Horn, also had a separate set of walls.[PARAGRAPH:2]These walls were almost inpenetrable, saving the city during sieges from the Bulgars, Arabs, and Rus', among others. The first attackers to break through the walls were the knights of the Fourth Crusade, who managed to scale the lower sea walls and also break the Wall of Leo in the northwestern Blachernae section of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The second and final time the walls were breached was during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, by the Ottomans; however, they did not break through by force, but entered through the Kerkoporta Gate, which happened to be open, apparently accidentally but possibly through treachery. A large plaque today marks the spot where the Ottomans entered. Mehmed had the walls repaired in short order among other massive public works projects. Within a few years, due to the renewed importance of the city as the new Ottoman capital, the population started to soar again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the Ottomans, the Golden Gate, known to them as Yedikule ("the Seven Towers"), was used as a prison. Many parts of the walls are still standing today and are a testament to the extraordinary longevity of the empire. They have been damaged by recent earthquakes, but many sections have also been restored. The wall runs through the suburbs of modern Istanbul, with a belt of parkland flanking their course. The walls are pierced at intervals by modern roads leading westwards out of the city.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The original walls of Constantinople were built in the 8th century BC when Byzantium was founded by Greek colonists from Megara. At the time the city consisted of an acropolis and little more. The colony was relatively unimportant by the Roman period, but Septimius Severus built a new set of walls during his reign, bringing more land into the city. When Constantine moved the capital of the empire to Byzantium, which he renamed Constantinople, he greatly expanded the walls of the city, incorporating even more territory.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 412 the Roman emperor Theodosius II surrounded Constantinople with a wall that stretched 6.5 kilometers between the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn. Although named after Theodosius, they were actually constructed under the direction of Anthemius, Praetorian prefect of the Eastern Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The walls were built of stone and brick in two lines of defense which adjoined a ditch 20 meters wide and 10 meters deep. The inner wall had was 5 meters thick and 12 meters high. It was strengthened with 96 unapproachable towers 18-20 meters tall. The thickness of the external wall was 2 meters, and its height was 8.5 meters. The wall contained the Belgrad, Silivrikapi, Mevlevihane, Topkapi, Edirnekapi, Egrikapi and Yedikule gates. Yedikule Gate was also known as the "Porta Aurea" or "Golden Gate", and was the most magnificent, consisting of three archways. As the state entrance into the capital, the Golden Gate was architecturally splendid, and was built of large square blocks of polished marble fitted together without cement, and flanked by two great towers of the same material. Upon the gates were placed sculpted elephants.[PARAGRAPH:2]The inner walls had massive square or hexagonal towers. The southern end of the walls, at the Sea of Marmara, was the location of the Marble Tower. There were ten gates, the four major ones being the Golden Gate at the southern end, the Selymbria Gate leading to the Forum of Constantine and Hagia Sophia, the Adrianople Gate connecting Constantinople's Mese (the main street) with the city of Adrianople and the Via Egnatia, and the Blachernae Gate in the north.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 439 the first sea walls were built. In 447 the wall was damaged by an earthquake, but was quickly restored in time to stop Attila's army. In the northwestern corner of the city, in the suburb of Blachernae, the Theodosian walls were relatively weaker, but were expanded by Leo I. The northern coast of the city, along the Golden Horn, also had a separate set of walls.[PARAGRAPH:2]These walls were almost inpenetrable, saving the city during sieges from the Bulgars, Arabs, and Rus', among others. The first attackers to break through the walls were the knights of the Fourth Crusade, who managed to scale the lower sea walls and also break the Wall of Leo in the northwestern Blachernae section of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The second and final time the walls were breached was during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, by the Ottomans; however, they did not break through by force, but entered through the Kerkoporta Gate, which happened to be open, apparently accidentally but possibly through treachery. A large plaque today marks the spot where the Ottomans entered. Mehmed had the walls repaired in short order among other massive public works projects. Within a few years, due to the renewed importance of the city as the new Ottoman capital, the population started to soar again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the Ottomans, the Golden Gate, known to them as Yedikule ("the Seven Towers"), was used as a prison. Many parts of the walls are still standing today and are a testament to the extraordinary longevity of the empire. They have been damaged by recent earthquakes, but many sections have also been restored. The wall runs through the suburbs of modern Istanbul, with a belt of parkland flanking their course. The walls are pierced at intervals by modern roads leading westwards out of the city.

TEXT.English: The Shrine of Uppsala

[TAB]The Shrine of Uppsala was a religious site in Gamla Uppsala (Old Uppsala), near modern Uppsala, Sweden, that was created to worship the Norse gods of prehistoric times. The cult site is sparsely documented, but it is referenced in the Norse sagas and Saxo Grammaticus' Gesta Danorum, and most notably as a gilded temple in the work of Adam of Bremen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Adam of Bremen wrote that the Swedes had a famous temple named Ubsola near which there was a large tree with wide branches. It was always green, and no one knew what species it was. There was also a well where they apparently used to perform the sacrifices. One of these was to immerse a living man in the well. If the man disappeared the gods would answer the prayers. It was not far from the towns of Sigtuna and Birka.[PARAGRAPH:2]A golden chain was around the temple hanging over its gables. The chain could be seen glittering far and wide for those who approached. It stood on flat ground surrounded by mounds like a theatre. Inside the temple, which was richly decorated with gold, there were three statues of gods. The most important god, Thor sat on a throne in the centre and beside him sat the gods Odin (called Wotan by Adam) and Freyr (called Fricco by Adam). Thor was said to govern the air, thunder, lightning, winds, rain, good weather and harvests. Odin, which meant the furious, brought war and gave strength against enemies. Freyr who gave peace and pleasure was represented by a statue with an immense phallos. Odin's statue was armed, and was likened to Mars and Thor was likened by Adam to Jupiter. The people also worshiped heroes who had been elevated to gods, such as King Erik about whom it is told in Vita Ansgari.[PARAGRAPH:2]There were priests appointed for the gods, and if plague or famine threatened they sacrificed to Thor, whereas they sacrificed to Odin for war and to Freyr for marriages.

Krak des Chevaliers

[TAB]Krak des Chevaliers ("fortress of the knights" in a mixture of Arabic and French) was the headquarters of the Knights Hospitaller in Syria during the Crusades. The castle is located east of Tripoli in the Homs Gap, atop a 650-meter high hill along the only route from Antioch to Beirut and the Mediterranean Sea. It is one of many fortresses part of a defensive network along the border of the old Crusader states.[PARAGRAPH:1]The original fortress had been built in 1031 for the emir of Aleppo. It was captured by Raymond IV of Toulouse early in 1099, during the First Crusade, but was abandoned when the Crusaders continued their march to Jerusalem. It was reoccupied again by Tancred, Prince of Galilee, in 1110. Raymond II, count of Tripoli, gave it to the Hospitallers in 1144. The Hospitallers rebuilt it and expanded it into the largest Crusader fortress in the Holy Land, adding an outer wall 3 meters thick with seven guard towers 8-10 meters thick, to create a concentric castle. One of these towers was occupied by the Grand Master of the Hospitallers. In the 12th century there was a moat covered by a drawbridge leading to postern gates.[PARAGRAPH:1] In 1163, the fortress was unsuccessfully besieged by Nur ad-Din. After their victory the Hospitallers became an essentially independent force on the Tripolitanian frontier. By 1170, the Hospitallers' modifications were complete, but parts of the fortress were rebuilt after numerous earthquakes in the late 12th century and early 13th century. It is estimated that the castle fortress could hold 50-60 Hospitallers and up to 2,000 foot soldiers. Aside from the control of the road to the Mediterranean, the Hospitallers also exerted some influence over Lake Homs to the east, where they could control the fishing industry and watch for Muslim armies gathering in Syria.[PARAGRAPH:1]Another failed siege was made by Saladin in 1188, during which the castle general was captured. He was taken by Saladin's men to the castle gates where he was told to order the gates opened. He first told his men in Arabic to surrender the castle, then in French told them to hold the castle to the last man. (Adapted from Wikipedia.org)

TEXT.English: Paço da Ribeira

The Ribeira Palace (Portuguese: Paço(s) da Ribeira) was Lisbon's royal palace for over 200 years, until it was destroyed by the 1755 Lisbon earthquake. The square in which the Palace was located is now one of the most important Lisbon squares, the Praça do Comércio.[PARAGRAPH:2]When staying in Lisbon during the Middle Ages, the Kings of Portugal would stay at Lisbon Castle, which crowns a high hill in the Alfama neighbourhood. In the 15th and early 16th centuries, maritime exploration during the Age of Discovery made Lisbon an increasingly important port city, responsible for the commerce between the nascent Portuguese Empire and Africa and India. In this context, King Manuel I decided, around 1500, to build a new royal palace on the banks of the Tagus river (the Ribeira), completely changing the urban landscape of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Ribeira Palace was finished around 1511. King Manuel I and the court were now close to the commercial and industrial heart of the city. The areas around the palace were occupied by the harbour, the shipbuilding area (the so-called Ribeira das Naus), customs and other buildings responsible for the regulation of maritime commerce.[PARAGRAPH:2]On the 1st of November of 1755, a huge earthquake, and resulting tsunami and fire destroyed the palace and most of Lisbon. King Joseph I was not at the palace and survived. His Prime Minister, the 1st Marquess of Pombal, coordinated a massive reconstruction effort that would give rise to the Pombaline Downtown of Lisbon. The royal family abandoned the Ribeira area and moved to palaces in the areas of Ajuda and Belém.
